block.para: In \RNr[2] the slanted box construction is applied to two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y}. Visually this is the parallelogram spanned by \Vect{x} and \Vect{y}.
Let us explain how this results from the definition of

Picture of \SltdBox{\Vect{x},\Vect{y}} Let X denote the point in \RNr[2] whose position vector is \Vect{x}. Then the vectors r \Vect{x} with 0\leq r\leq 1 are the position vectors for points on the line segment [\Vect{0},X] joining the origin to X.

Now a vector sum of the form r \Vect{x} + s \Vect{y} with 0\leq r\leq 1 parallel translates the line segment [0,X] by the vector s \Vect{y}. As 0\leq s\leq 1, these parallel translated line segments fill the parallelogram spanned by \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} as shown.
Here is another example of such a parallelogram, the slanted box spanned by vectors \Vect{u} and \Vect{v}.
